STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 12, 2025
Renee Villegas
BRANCH COUNTY DHHS
388 KEITH WILHELM DR,
COLDWATER, MI, 49036-8244
RE: License#: CP120200999
Dear Renee Villegas:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/8-9/12/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the WOC area manager, Shay Mavis, at 269-243-2725.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.
Three of Three files of open foster homes reviewed contained reevaluation
reports that did not include the family's placement preferences regarding youths'
SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names
of persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of Three files of open foster homes reviewed contained a special evaluation
report that did not include documentation of an investigation (interviews,
documents reviewed, etc.) within the report. Additionally, notes attached to the

report documented interviews conducted; however the notes were not clear that a
licensing investigation was completed.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of Six files of youths currently in foster care placements reviewed contained
two updated service plans not completed timely. One report was completed 1 day
late and the other 3 days late.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R 400.12418(5) - If Parent Agency Treatment Plans are being provided
electronically due to courtesy workers making in person contacts, there must
be documentation the document was reviewed with all parties. This could be
done via video conferencing or by phone, if needed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R 400.12418(6) - Uploading worker and supervisor signatures on service
plans and parent agency treatment plans at the time the documents are
signed would prevent the need to locate and upload these documents at the
time of inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The one CAP submitted by the agency during the period under review was
submitted in response to the 12/20/24 licensing inspection report and was
approved on 1/6/2024. That CAP addressed two violations; R 400.12421(2) and R
400.12413(1(e.) Each of those violations was found in one of the six open foster
care files reviewed. The violations were effectively addressed through the CAP as
evidenced by no repeat violations being established.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator’s assessment dated 8/26/2025 identified areas of
significant compliance such as initial physical exams, periodic well child exams,
initial dental exams, worker-child contacts, and return home contacts. Some
challenges with compliance identified were sibling visits as there have been large
sibling groups in which coordinating visits has been challenging as well as social
work contact entry. During the entrance meeting, the chief administrator and
agency leadership identified an increase in child removals throughout the year
resulting in an increase in caseloads. Additionally, difficulty maintaining stable and
appropriate placements for youths with aggressive and mental health needs
results in workers needing to shift focus from their planned work activities to
securing placements. These factors have put some strain on staff ability to
maintain full compliance with all timeframe requirements.
Financial Overview
Not Applicable.
Staff Interviews
Two of the three staff members interviewed started their individual interviews by
stating they are "drowning." All three of the staff members interviewed reported
being within caseload compliance; however, the caseload numbers are higher
than what they typically carry at the agency. The two foster care workers
interviewed reported there has been an increase in challenging cases related to
court orders requiring services to be provided in cases where services would not
have typically been court ordered. They all reported that, despite the increase in
workload, they all feel supported and assisted by management, they reported
there is an understanding by supervisors as well as the agency director as to the
difficulty completing all tasks timely and assistance is provided when needed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have adequate space and equipment to provide for the
delivery of foster care, independent living, and certification services. Case records
are stored in a locked file room and closed adoption records are stored within a
dedicated locked cabinet in a supervisor's office. Physical CHRI is stored in a
separate locked cabinet.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
September 12, 2025
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 12, 2025
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
WOC Area Manager
